knowledge_base.title: Emergency Triage Basic Principles
knowledge_base.content: Emergency triage is the process of assigning patients to different priority treatment areas based on the urgency and severity of their condition. Basic principles include: 1) Vital signs assessment priority; 2) Symptom severity grading; 3) Time sensitivity consideration; 4) Resource allocation optimization.

knowledge_base.title: Emergency Triage Classification Standards
knowledge_base.content: According to international standards, emergency triage is typically divided into 5 levels: Level 1 (Critical) - immediate rescue; Level 2 (Severe) - treatment within 10 minutes; Level 3 (Urgent) - treatment within 30 minutes; Level 4 (Less urgent) - treatment within 60 minutes; Level 5 (Non-urgent) - treatment within 120 minutes.

knowledge_base.title: Readmission Risk Factors
knowledge_base.content: Key risk factors for hospital readmission include: 1) Previous admission history; 2) Chronic disease burden; 3) Age and comorbidities; 4) Social determinants of health; 5) Medication adherence; 6) Follow-up care quality.

knowledge_base.title: Medication Recommendation Principles
knowledge_base.content: Medication recommendation principles include: 1) Evidence-based selection; 2) Patient-specific factors; 3) Drug interactions consideration; 4) Dosage optimization; 5) Safety monitoring; 6) Cost-effectiveness analysis.

knowledge_base.title: Drug-Drug Interaction (DDI) Detection
knowledge_base.content: DDI detection involves: 1) Pharmacokinetic interactions (absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion); 2) Pharmacodynamic interactions (synergistic, antagonistic effects); 3) Severity classification (minor, moderate, major, contraindicated); 4) Clinical significance assessment; 5) Management strategies and monitoring recommendations.
